title: Solution for issue 17
Fix a bug in the log_entropy_model
body:
The previous implementation had the mistake that it divided by the context diversity of a term instead of the total number of documents. It happened because I read it from a paper where the notation was misleading. Of course it could not be like this because then all terms with a context diversity of 1 would lead to a division by zero. 

For reference of the normalization see: 
Pincombe, B. (2004). Comparison of human and LSA judgements of pairwise document similarities for a news corpus. dspace.dsto.defence.gov.au.

also the tests are changed to fit the new implementation

title: Automated test to reproduce the results of Lee et al. (2005)
body:
Lee et al. (2005) compares different models for semantic
similarity and verifies the results with similarity judgements from humans.
The main result is that semantic similarites modelled by LSA have a correlation
of 0.6 with human similarity judgements.
As a validation of the gensim implementation we reproduced the results
of  Lee et al. (2005) in this test.

Many thanks to Michael D. Lee (michael.lee@adelaide.edu.au) who provideded us
with his corpus and similarity data.

If you need to reference this dataset, please cite:

Lee, M., Pincombe, B., & Welsh, M. (2005).
An empirical evaluation of models of text document similarity.
Proceedings of the 27th Annual Conference of the Cognitive Science Society

title: Luca
body:
This is a small change that eliminates category names from the pages being analyzed. 
With the previous analysis, if a page belonged e.g. to the categories Physics, Engineering, then these words would be added to the end of the text of the page, due to the way in which the link processing works. 
I think this creates artificially strong (even though perhaps beneficial?) correlations between category names, and the words used in the articles belonging to the categories, and so, I eliminated the category links from the text passed for analysis. 
My goal was to have text that was more similar to the text used in the description of something, rather than also all the organizational links. 
I apologize for the wrong commit date of Aug 5.  It's a problem due to the date in the virtual machine where I run the tool being wrong.

title: Added option for tf-length-normalization to models.TfidfModel
body:
See the discussion in the mailing list: http://groups.google.com/group/gensim/browse_thread/thread/11e19beedd70470c

This implementation calculates the document length (not geometric length!) for each vector and applies the following division to each of the vector's components: `tf / document_length`.

This is done before tf is multiplied with idf.

title: Improve wikimedia markup filtering.
body:
I am improving the filtering of:
1. Templates
   The current implementation uses a regular expression. This is problematic when there are nested templates. I am replacing this by the function `remove_template`. This function find the location of the opening '{{' and closing '}}' for each template. Then it uses these locations to remove the templates from the text.
2. 'File:'/'Image:' markup
   The current regular expression used to filter these markups sometimes fails. I am replacing this by the function `remove_file`. This function first find all the 'File:'/'Image:' markups using a regular expression, and then replace each instance by their corresponding captions.

title: Gardening/Fix Dictionary load/save
body: `corpora.dictionary.Dictionary` decodes/encodes data on load/save

title: Optimize Porter stemming
body:
I took the liberty of optimizing the Porter stemmer, cleaning up the code as I went. The result is roughly 20% faster than the original, as measured by running the script

```
from gensim.parsing.preprocessing import PorterStemmer

st = PorterStemmer()

for ln in open("/usr/share/dict/american-english-insane"):
    st.stem(ln.strip())
```

where `american-english-insane` is the dictionary file from the Ubuntu package [`wamerican-insane`](http://packages.ubuntu.com/precise/wamerican-insane). When I add a print statement in the loop, results are exactly the same before and after optimization. The unit test also passes.

I removed the option the stem a substring of a string; it wasn't being used by Gensim and doesn't really make sense. Callers can take a substring themselves.

The stemmer now also does lowercasing itself.

The comments have been stripped of references to pointers and NUL bytes that only made sense in the context of the original C implementation.

(The code still isn't very Pythonic, but it's closer to that ideal now.)

title: Proper XML parser for Wikipedia dumps
body:
I've reworked the Wikipedia dump parser in `gensim.corpora.wikicorpus` to use a proper XML parser, instead of the line-oriented parser used now. Experiments on smaller versions of Wikipedia, such as the Norwegian one, show that parsing speed is roughly unchanged.

The main benefit of this approach is that articles can be pruned earlier, e.g. based on the title or the namespace (a user may want to consider only articles from the main namespace, with titles not matching `^List of`, etc.). Also, error handling is improved as the parser checks whether what it gets is XML, and looks like a MediaWiki dump. I think there is also some more room for optimization.

Please let me know what you think.

title: HashDictionary
body:
This addresses issue #76 - I couldn't help taking a pass at it! (apologies to @raoshivani)

The `HashDictionary` is based on `Dictionary` and is very similar. The tests are also based on the tests for `Dictionary`. There's a debug option which will keep track of collisions in the hash's range (as sets).

The class `gensim.corpora.RestrictedHash` contains most the logic for imitating the `token2id` dict. The hash function is exposed as a construction argument. The default hash function is `zlib.adler32`, for no particularly good reason. Let me know if you have any feedback!

title: eat newline when present in binary dfformat
body:
fixes issue with binary models. Some models have a newline after the word vectors, some do not. 

From the hexdump analysis on an older trained file (from a few weeks ago)

1b bd 0a 73 65 76 65 6e  20 81 29 06 be 69 52 60  |...seven .)..iR`

notice that before the new word there is indeed a newline (bold), yet in the freebase model 

00001f70  00 00 cc 3c 2f 65 6e 2f  62 61 72 61 63 6b 5f 6f  |...</en/barack_o|

there is no newline, the 2f is / - the first character of the new word. I looked at distance.c and the line

```
fscanf(f, "%s%c", &vocab[b * max_w], &ch);
```

fscanf (used in the word2vec c code) ignores leading and training whitespace, emulating this behavior in python fixes this issue.

title: Create a dictionary that maps document id to some metadata of the original corpus
body: This commit parses the Wikipedia Page id and title as metadata, and creates a Python dictionary that maps from gensim doc id to  to the metadata. It also changes the serialization so that the dictionary is stored in a pickle file. Other corpus classes can also be modified to support generating a metadata dictionary, but with the default argument the changes shouldn't effect corpus classes other than WikiCorpus. It also shouldn't effect the behavior of the WikiCorpus class if no additional parameters were specified.

title: Filter wikipedia articles by their namespace
body:
Adds the ability to skip article with certain namespace in Wikipedia. These are Wikipedia entries that are images file, audio files, templates, user profiles, ..., etc. The full list can be found here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Namespace .

This commit does not change the currently behavior of the WikiCorpus class, unless the additional filter_namespaces argument is passed to the initializer.

For example,

WikiCorpus( inp, lemmatize=lemmatize, filter_namespaces=('0','2') )

will only include main articles and user profile pages into the corpus, while 

WikiCorpus( inp, lemmatize=lemmatize )

will be the same as the current behavior, using all entries in the Wikipedia dump.

title: Enabling saving/loading vocabulary alongside word2vec dump
body:
Hello Radim,

Curious to know what you think about the following patch. Right now the vocabulary counts loaded from a word2vec model in gensim are misleading. This patch enables the output of SaveVocab() in word2vec to be used to restore the 'right' counts for words in the vocabulary. It also enables save_word2vec_format to persist a vocabulary file alongside the model (with real counts).

Best,
y

title: Parameterize LdaModel variational magic numbers
body:
This commit removes the VAR_MAXITER and VAR_THRESH constants from
LdaModel and allows each to be set when a new model is made, or
during a call to update(). They have been named iterations and
gamma_threshold.

Logging messages for the number of passes were changed to use the word
"pass" instead of "iteration", to avoid any confusion. Other logging
messages were also updated to include these vars.

This is a non-automatic fix for Issue #58.

title: [Word2Vec] Support for reading calculated skip ngrams
body:
This adds support for training from precompiled skip ngrams, instead of raw text. Each ``sentence" from the corpus reader now consists of the following format ([str:word1, str:word2], int:distance, int:count). This is useful if you are trying to train a word2vec model from a ngram model, for example the Google Web1T dataset. Both the Python and Cython implementations were updated.

New functionalities are controlled by the skip_ngram parameter, with the default value the behavior of existing functionalities should remain the same.

I wasn't sure how to change the matrix manipulation part, so each skip ngrams with counts will update the matrix multiple times. This is likely to be very inefficient, and should be improved in the future.

title: CBOW
body:
I have added the CBOW functionality.

It should replicate the original code by Mikolov et al., except that it combines context words by taking the average of the corresponding vectors instead of their sum. This is in agreement with the textual description of the CBOW model in [1](although Figure 1 in that paper says).

Here are some baseline results on the Google analogy dataset (questions-words.txt) with the vocabulary restricted to the 30,000 most frequent words. The training corpora are the "text8" and "fil9" datasets found at "http://mattmahoney.net/dc/textdata.html". In all cases, I used vectors of dimension 640 and a window of size 10. The rest of the hyper-parameters take their default value.

With "text8":

Skip-gram: 29.3% correct
CBOW: 15.5% (11.5% if I used the sum of the vectors instead of their average)

With "fil9":

Skip-gram: 52.5%
CBOW: 46.2% (29.9% using the sum)

Note: By default, my system always used "Optimization 1" during training. What would be the most efficient way to test the other optimizations before incorporating the changes into Gensim?

---

[1] Tomas Mikolov, Kai Chen, Greg Corrado, and Jeffrey Dean. Efficient Estimation of Word Representations in Vector Space. In Proceedings of Workshop at ICLR, 2013.

@piskvorky, I hope this fixes the Dictionary issue. It uses the Mapping mixin rather than inheritance from dict. Open question is whether Dictionary should behave like a Py2 dict even in Py3; currently it doesn't and I think it would break the Py3 Mapping contract to do so.

title: Py3k
body:
All tests pass, but this is still work-in-progress, because all tutorials/docs need to be updated too (NOTE: look into ipy notebooks, #180 ).

Changes aim to be backward compatible, but the new official gensim API will recommend **using unicode wherever strings are expected** (now: asks for utf8). Starting with Python 3.3, there's no longer a huge memory overhead to (mostly-ASCII) unicode strings. Python 2 will take a memory hit though.

Highlights:
- All I/O is binary, converted to unicode explicitly inside gensim (=not using the py3k `encoding` params to `open`&co). Uses `utils.smart_open()` consistently.
- All internally stored tokens/keys are expected to be unicode now. Find bytestring/ambiguity => file a bug.
- Need more backward compatibility tests = make sure utf8 inputs continue to work. Don't want the same migration drama py3 itself is having!
- I think this warrants a full version bump => `0.10.0`

Ping @larsmans @simonzack @moustaki can you please run `setup.py test` unit tests on your machines? I'll ping Steph for a Windows run too.

title: Unbundle Six and Cythonize setup by bulding an optional "addons" package
body:
This pull request unbundles Six (available from pypi) and adds some extra options to setup.py, so there will be an additional "addons"-package if Cython is installed on the user's system.  This "addons"-package avoids the need for building the so-extension during runtime (although this probability is still available after the changes) .

For a good reason I've removed the hashbang from libraries' files and also fixed the executable permissions on the files.  A lib should NOT have executable files NOR hashbangs, because the python-files are not intended to be called in "script-like-style", but from inside some python-code (which might be a script).

title: Added DTM wrapper, supports training on a corpus
body:
## What is included
- Initial implementation for the DTM wrapper. Made it look  like the Malletwrapper as much as possible (for consistency)
- Included a test_dtm script  to test out the model. I thought of putting this in the unittest, but was not sure. 
- Computes Influence Model by default
- Computes on any corpus that can be transoformed to BleiCorpus and has len (currently a part of my own research corpus is used).
## To Run the test_script
- You just need to set the DTM_HOME variable or just supply the path to the binary.
- You can get the binaries either by compiling them from the  [original](https://code.google.com/p/princeton-statistical-learning/downloads/detailname=dtm_release.tgz&can=2&q=) or a [fork](https://github.com/magsilva/dtm) ,which also has precompiled binaries for Linux and Windows.
- Supply another corpus if you wish .
## What is missing
- Inference on a holdout corpus.
- Tests
- Some comments and parameter explanations

P,S Still slightly new to the world of contributing with git. Please point out obvious mistakes.

title: [word2vec] 'sample' parameter, for frequent-word down-sampling
body:
Implements 'sample' parameter for down-sampling of frequent words. Interpretation of parameter follows original C word2vec formula. (Word frequencies actually need to be about 2.6x the parameter before their odds-of-inclusion fall below 1.0.)

When down-sampling is enabled, the 'total_words' value used for progress-estimation and alpha-updating is an estimate. (So, final progress update my indicate a value over 100%.) Sampling-probabilities for frequent words are precalculated and stored in the Vocab objects to avoid constant recalculation during training. 

Un-sampled words are removed from the sentences, rather than replaced by `None`. Additionally, the handling of out-of-vocabulary words has been changed to remove such words, rather than replace them with `None`. In both cases, this matches my understanding of what the original C word2vec does, and a series of short trials using the 'text8' corpus shows slight accuracy improvements against the question-words.txt accuracy check.

title: Support for matrix-valued topic/word prior eta in LdaModel.
body:
This allows topics to be seeded with specific words. (Or however you like, really. It could e.g. be used to impose a fixed background topic if you specify the prior for one topic to have a specific base measure and a really high concentration)

This is quite a small patch, it looks like the only place which needs changing to handle a matrix for eta is the computation of the variational bound.

Added a test for the seeding behaviour, although like the existing testTransform test it's just a high-level sanity check.

title: Fix length for corpora on empty files
Refactor corpus tests
body:
Also ensures that all possible temp test files are removed

Not a whole lot of changes here, mainly changing CorpusTester to be a concrete class. Needed to do this because some temporary test files were not being removed and could cause multiple test runs to fail.

Just looking for comments & approval before merge.

title: Added ability to specify token map in Dictionary.from_corpus
body:
In cases where the BOW matrix is given along with an id -> token map,
this feature allow for a perfect reconstruction of the dictionary
object using the `from_corpus` method.

title: Doc Fix: LSI --> LSA
body: The title says it all.

title: Adding the word2vect n_similarity method
body: Everything should be in the code comments. This is pretty useful to compare n grams.
